title: Fire Safety Engineering Education: Cognitive Load Theory and Constructivist-Based Design

context.prior_knowledge: Foundational engineering knowledge and basic understanding of pedagogy
context.additional_context: Systematically Designed Course for Pre-Service/In-Service Teachers with Diverse Academic Backgrounds to Acquire Fire Safety Engineering Concepts, Minimizing Cognitive Load While Promoting Active Learning Through Constructivist Approaches

learning_goals: Learners can explain core principles of fire safety engineering, including combustion, smoke spread, and structural design.
Learners can analyze real-world cases to design and evaluate fire prevention and response strategies.
Learners can present instructional design approaches applying cognitive load theory to develop teaching strategies suitable for learners with diverse backgrounds.
Learners can apply fire safety concepts to real-life problems through constructivist-based activities (discussions, case studies, collaborative learning).
difficulty: Hard - Complex requirements with multiple constraints
